item.title: Axiom of Choice (AC)
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Let be a set of non-empty sets, the axiom of choice (AC) asserts that there exists a choice functionfunction such that for every set ,
Informally, assigns to each set in a member of that set.
Each choice function corresponds to one element in the cartesian product of the elements of the collection . Therefore, another way to state the AC is
Given any family/collection of non-empty sets , their cartesian product is a nonempty set
Another way
Properties
Equivalent to: Zorn's LemmaZorn's Lemma
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

item.title: Cardinality
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Each set is assigned a certain object, called the cardinal number (or cardinality) of (), in such a way that two sets are assigned the same cardinality iff they are equinumerousequinumerous
All infinite sets are big, however some are bigger than other. Cardinal numbers generalize “set size” to infinite sets.
For finite sets, the standard definition of cardinality is the number of members of the set.
Properties
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

item.title: Chain
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Let be a set with an ordering relationordering relation . A subset is a chain iff for any two elements , either or
A chain is a totally ordered subset of a posetposet
The chain has an upper bound iff for every element ,
EXAMPLE
If is a set of sets and the ordering relation is : A collection of sets is a chain iff for any elements (sets) and in , either or
The upper bound of is
Properties
By definition, a finite chain always has an upper bound. However, not every chain needs to have an upper bound.
EXAMPLES
Consider set $\N$ with ordering relation . Let chain . has no upper bound because for any element there is always a bigger number
Another example is the set , the set of rational numbers less than . Which is a chain, does not have an upper bound
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

item.title: Countable
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A set is countable iff there is some one-to-one functionfunction mapping set to the set of natural numbers ()

Properties
L1. Let be a countably infinite set with one-one counting function . Then, we can extract a one-one onto counting function [1]
T1. Let be a countable set, then the set of all finite sequences of members of is also countable[2]
See Also


For some , is the least member of $ran$(), let
In general, there is some unique such that is the th least member of $ran$(), let ↩︎
For each finite sequence , assign number where is the th prime number and is the counting function of set ↩︎
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

item.title: Cycle
item.description:
abiteboul1995foundationsabiteboul1995foundations
A cycle is a path such that and
A directed cycle is proper if is a proper path
An undirected cycle is proper if is a proper path and [1]
Properties
If has a cycle from , then has a proper cycle from
See Also


Why ? In theory it can be a cycle, but it doesn’t look like a cycle because the same edge between two vertices qualifies for a cycle↩︎
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

item.title: Equinumerosity
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Two sets and are equinumerous () iff there is a one-to-one onto functionfunction mapping onto
EXAMPLE
$\N$ and $\Z$ are equinumerous
Properties
Equinumerosity is reflexive, symmetric and transitivetransitive
Two finite sets have the same “size” iff they are equinumerous
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical

item.title: n-Tuple
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
An n-tuple is an extension of ordered pairs to include objects. It’s defined recursively

Properties
L1. Every -tuple is an ordered pair

L2. If , then [1]

L3. If , then [2]

C1. If , both n-tuples are finite sequences of set and no member or is a finite sequence of other elements in then and

See Also

Finite Sequence


Can be shown using induction on ↩︎

item.title: Ordering Relation
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A binary relation defined on a set is an ordering relation if it allows for comparing elements of set . Ordering relations typically satisfy properties like TransitivityTransitivity and Trichotomy
There are two types of ordering relations: Partial OrderPartial Order and Total Order.
When unspecified, an ordering relation usually refers to a total order.

Should ordering relations be reflexive?
Properties
See Also
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

item.title: Pairwise Disjoint
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A collection of sets (a set of sets) is pairwise disjoint iff any two members of the collection are disjoint i.e. their intersection is $\varnothing$
Properties
See Also
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

item.title: Partial Order
item.description:
abiteboul1995foundationsabiteboul1995foundations
A partial order of is an ordering relationordering relation over that is

reflexive,
antisymmetric, and
transitivetransitive.
The ordered pair is a partially ordered set (poset).
A partial order allows for comparing some elements of
Properties
See Also

Ordering RelationOrdering Relation
Total Order

item.title: Transitive Relation
item.description:
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
A relation is transitive iff whenever both ordered pairs , then

item.title: Tree
item.description:
abiteboul1995foundationsabiteboul1995foundations
A tree is a graph that has exactly one vertex with no in-edges (called the root) and no undirected cyclesundirected cycles
For each vertex , there is a unique proper path from root to
A leaf is a vertex of a tree with no out-edges
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
For each tree, there is a finite partial orderingpartial ordering . If , then is lower than and connected by a line.
Properties
A tree is connected but not strongly connected
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri

item.title: Zorn's Lemma
item.description:
#todo
enderton2001mathematicalenderton2001mathematical
Let be a set with an ordering relationordering relation such that for any chainchain , the upper boundupper bound of exists and is in . Then, there is some element which is maximal i.e. for any element , either or and are incomparable wrt
EXAMPLE
Let be a set of sets such that for any chainchain , the upper bound . Then, there is some element which is maximal i.e. it is not a subset of any other element of
Properties
Equivalent to: Axiom of Choice (AC)Axiom of Choice (AC)

#todo How is Zorn’s Lemma related to the Axiom of Choice?

item.title: A Mathematical Introduction to Logic
item.description:
(enderton2001mathematical, p.xi)
Symbolic logic is a mathematical model of deductive thought
(enderton2001mathematical, p.xii)
The logical correctness of these deductions is due to their form but is independent of their content.
enderton2001mathematical, p.xii
Is there a gap between what we can prove in an axiomatic system (say for the natural numbers) and what is true about the natural numbers?
What is the connection between logic and computability?
(enderton2001mathematical, p.xii)
This book does not propose to teach the reader how to think. The word “logic” is sometimes used to refer to remedial thinking, but not by us. The reader already knows how to think.


Chapter 0 - Useful Facts about SetsChapter 0 - Useful Facts about Sets
Chapter 1 - Sentential LogicChapter 1 - Sentential Logic
Chapter 2 - First-Order LogicChapter 2 - First-Order Logic
Chapter 3 - UndecidabilityChapter 3 - Undecidability
Chapter 4 - Second-Order LogicChapter 4 - Second-Order Logic
item.dc:creator: Jayitha Cherapanamjeri
